contextId.glQuote: in the land
contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the land of Israel. Alternate translation: "in the land of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: she had heard in the country of Moab
contextId.occurrenceNote: "while Naomi was living in Moab she heard." It is implied that the news came from Israel. Alternate translation: "she heard from Israel while in the region of Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: I am too old to have a husband
contextId.occurrenceNote: The reason a husband would be important can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "too old to marry again and bear more children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: but Ruth held on to her
contextId.occurrenceNote: "Ruth clung to her." Alternate translation: "Ruth refused to leave her" or "Ruth would not leave her" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: your people will be my people
contextId.occurrenceNote: Ruth is referring to Naomi's people, the Israelites. Alternate translation: "I will consider the people of your country as being my own people" or "I will consider your relatives as my own relatives" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: She lifted it up and went into the city
contextId.occurrenceNote: It is implied that Ruth carried the grain home. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: young female workers you were with
contextId.occurrenceNote: The translation can make explicit that she was working in the fields with these female workers. Alternate translation: "female workers you have been with in the fields" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: if he will redeem you
contextId.occurrenceNote: Boaz is referring to the expectation that the closest male relative of Ruth's dead husband would marry her and help carry on his family name. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: How did it go, my daughter?
contextId.occurrenceNote: What Ruth meant by this question can be made more clear. Alternate translation: "What happened, my daughter?" or "How did Boaz act toward you?" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: the father of David
contextId.occurrenceNote: "father of King David." Though "king" is not stated, it was clear to the original audience that David was King David. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])

contextId.glQuote: about an ephah of barley
contextId.occurrenceNote: An ephah is a unit of measurement equal to about 22 liters. Alternate translation: "about 22 liters of barley" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-bvolume]])

contextId.glQuote: Bitter
contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a translation of the meaning of the name. It is also often translated according to its sound as "Mara." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

contextId.glQuote: Hezron ... Ram
contextId.occurrenceNote: (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-names]])

contextId.glQuote: uncover his feet
contextId.occurrenceNote: This means to remove the cloak or blanket covering his feet so that they would be exposed to the cold. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])

contextId.glQuote: Now Naomi had a relative of her husband
contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase introduces new information before the story continues. Your language may have a way to introduce new information. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])

contextId.glQuote: Now this was the custom
contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer of the book explains of the custom of exchange during the time of Ruth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])

contextId.glQuote: in former times
contextId.occurrenceNote: "in earlier times." This implies that the customs had changed from when the story took place until the book was written. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/writing-background]])

contextId.glQuote: So Naomi returned, with Ruth
contextId.occurrenceNote: This begins a summary statement. English marks this by the word "so." Determine how your language marks concluding or summary statements and do the same. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/writing-endofstory]])

contextId.glQuote: It happened that
contextId.occurrenceNote: "It came about." This is marking a new story line. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/writing-newevent]])

contextId.glQuote: who has not forsaken his loving kindness
contextId.occurrenceNote: "who has continued to be loyal." Possible meanings are 1) Boaz remembered his obligations to Naomi as a family member or 2) Naomi is referring to Yahweh, who was acting through Boaz or 3) Yahweh has continued to be faithful to the living and the dead. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

contextId.glQuote: who has not left you today without a kinsman=redeemer
contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase can be expressed positively. Alternate translation: "who has provided you today with a near kinsman" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])

contextId.glQuote: He went in to her
contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a euphemism that refers to having sexual intercourse. Alternate translation: "He had sexual relations with her" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])

contextId.glQuote: took wives
contextId.occurrenceNote: "married women." This is an idiom for marrying women. They did not take women who were already married. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: they walked down the road
contextId.occurrenceNote: "they walked along the road." To walk down a road is an expression for walking away. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: with the dead
contextId.occurrenceNote: "to your husbands, who died." Naomi was referring to her two sons that died. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: and they lifted up their voices and cried
contextId.occurrenceNote: To raise the voice is an idiom for speaking loudly. The daughters cried out loud or wept bitterly. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: Then they lifted up their voices and cried
contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that they cried out loud or wept bitterly. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: Where you die, I will die
contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Ruth's desire to spend the rest of her life living in the same place and town as Naomi. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: May Yahweh do to me, and even more, if
contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to Ruth asking God to punish her if she does not do what she said like the english idiom "God forbid, if." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: in whose eyes I will find favor
contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "found favor" is an idiom which means to be approved of by someone. Ruth speaks of gaining someone's favor as gaining permission or approval. Also, the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts and judgement. Alternate translation: "who will grant me permission to glean" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

contextId.glQuote: my daughter
contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a kind way of addressing a younger woman. Ruth was not the actual daughter of Boaz, so make sure the translation of this does not make it sound like she was. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: Let me find favor in your eyes
contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "find favor" is an idiom that means be approved of or that he is pleased with her. Here "eyes" are a metonym for sight, and  sight is a metaphor representing his evaluation. Alternate translation: "Please accept me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.glQuote: go down to the threshing floor
contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to leaving the city and heading to the threshing area. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: He turned over
contextId.occurrenceNote: He looked to see what startled him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: Spread your cloak over your female servant
contextId.occurrenceNote: This was a cultural idiom for marriage. Alternate translation: "Marry me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: because you have not gone after
contextId.occurrenceNote: "you have not pursued marriage with." Ruth could have ignored Naomi's need and looked for a husband for herself outside of Naomi's relatives. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: you must also acquire Ruth
contextId.occurrenceNote: "you must also marry Ruth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: better to you than seven sons
contextId.occurrenceNote: "Seven" was the Hebrew number of completeness. Naomi's sons both died before they produced any offspring, but Ruth bore a grandson to Naomi by Boaz. Alternate translation: "better to you than any son" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])

contextId.glQuote: It is exceedingly bitter to me
contextId.occurrenceNote: Bitterness is a metaphor for grief, and what grieves her can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "It greatly grieves me that you have no husbands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor or figs-explicit]] and

contextId.glQuote: under whose wings you have come for refuge
contextId.occurrenceNote: Boaz uses the picture of a mother bird gathering her chicks under her wings to protect them, in order to describe God's protection for those who trust in him. Alternate translation: "in whose safe care you have placed yourself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.glQuote: rest for you
contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) literally in finding a house for her to live in or 2) figuratively in finding a husband to care for her. Naomi probably had both senses in mind. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.glQuote: so that his name will not be cut off from among his brothers and from the gate of his place
contextId.occurrenceNote: Being forgotten is spoken of as if one's name were being cut off from a list of people who had lived earlier. Alternate translation: "so that he will not be forgotten by his brothers' descendants and the people of this town" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.glQuote: is coming into your house
contextId.occurrenceNote: This has literal and figurative meaning. As Ruth marries Boaz, she will move into his house. House can also refer to becoming part of Boaz's family by being his wife. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.glQuote: May your house be like the house
contextId.occurrenceNote: God abundantly blessed Judah through his son Perez. The people were asking God to bless Boaz in a similar way through Ruth's children. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.glQuote: in the house of her husband
contextId.occurrenceNote: with their new husbands, not someone else's husband. This refers to both a physical house that belongs to the husband, and to the protection from shame by being married. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

contextId.glQuote: the hand of Yahweh has gone out against me
contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" refers to Yahweh's power or influence. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has caused terrible things to happen to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

contextId.glQuote: the entire town
contextId.occurrenceNote: The "town" refer to the people who live there. Alternate translation: "everyone in the town" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

contextId.glQuote: Keep your eyes on the field
contextId.occurrenceNote: The eyes represent watching something or paying attention to something. Alternate translation: "Watch only the field" or "Pay attention only to the field" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

contextId.glQuote: have come to a people
contextId.occurrenceNote: Boaz is referring to Ruth coming to dwell with Naomi in a village and community, a country, and religion she did not know. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])

contextId.glQuote: may full payment be given to you by Yahweh
contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a poetic expression that is very similar to the previous sentence. Alternate translation: "May Yahweh give back to you even more than you have given" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

contextId.glQuote: Where have you gleaned today, and where did you work?
contextId.occurrenceNote: Naomi said almost the same thing in two different ways to show that she was very interested in knowing what had happened to Ruth that day. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

contextId.glQuote: That man is our relative, one of our kinsman-redeemers
contextId.occurrenceNote: The second phrase repeats and expands the first. This is a Hebrew style of emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])

contextId.glQuote: Why will you go with me?
contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a rhetorical question. Alternate translation: "It does not make sense for you to go with me." or "You should not go with me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: Are there still sons in my womb, that they may become your husbands?
contextId.occurrenceNote: Naomi uses this question to say she cannot have other sons for them to marry. Alternate translation: "Obviously it is not possible for me to have any more sons who could become your husbands." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: would you therefore wait until they were grown? Would you keep yourselves from having a husband?
contextId.occurrenceNote: These are rhetorical questions, which do not expect an answer. Alternate translation: "you would not wait until they were grown up so that you could marry them. You would choose to marry a husband now." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: Will you not listen to me, my daughter?
contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be reworded as a command. Alternate translation: "Listen to me, my daughter" or "Note well what I am telling you, my daughter" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: Have I not instructed the young men not to touch you?
contextId.occurrenceNote: Boaz used this question to emphasize what he had already done to help Ruth. Alternate translation: "I have given the men strict instructions ... you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: should I not seek rest for you ... with you?
contextId.occurrenceNote: Naomi uses this question to tell Ruth what she planned to do. Alternate translation: "I must look for a place for you to rest ... for you." or "I must find a husband to care for you ... for you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: is he not our kinsman?
contextId.occurrenceNote: Naomi probably used this question to remind Ruth of something she had already told her. Alternate translation: "he is our relative." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])

contextId.glQuote: his heart was merry
contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Boaz is referred to by his heart. It does not imply Boaz was overly drunk. Alternate translation: "he was satisfied" or "he was in a good mood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

contextId.glQuote: from the hand of Naomi
contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents Naomi, who owns the field. Alternate translation: "from Naomi" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

contextId.glQuote: from the hand of Naomi
contextId.occurrenceNote: The hand of Naomi represents Naomi. She was responsible for the money exchange. Alternate translation: "from Naomi" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])

contextId.glQuote: at the beginning of the barley harvest
contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "the barley harvest" can be translated with a verbal phrase. Alternate translation: "when the farmers were just beginning to harvest barley" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])

contextId.glQuote: It has surely been reported to me
contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "People have reported to me" or "People have told me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])

contextId.glQuote: we will return
contextId.occurrenceNote: When Orpah and Ruth said "we," they were referring to themselves and not Naomi. So languages that have inclusive and exclusive "we" would use the exclusive form here. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-exclusive]])

contextId.glQuote: and to the dead
contextId.occurrenceNote: Naomi's husband and sons were the "dead." This can be stated differently to remove the nominal adjective "the dead." Alternate translation: "the people who have already died" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-nominaladj]])

contextId.glQuote: each of you
contextId.occurrenceNote: Naomi was talking to two people, so languages that have a dual form of "you" would use that throughout her talk. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])

contextId.glQuote: with you
contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "you" is the singular form referring to Naomi. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
